source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_029_chunk1
evidence_span: Three modifications of $\mathbf { Z } \mathbf { r } { - } 2 . 5 \mathbf { N } \mathbf { b }$ material have been irradiated at $\$ 53\mathrm { \texttt { K } }$ to high fast fluences of $3 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 } \mathrm { n } / \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 }$

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_029_chunk1

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_029_chunk1
evidence_span: Pressure tube elongation is the main problem with elongation rates of 3 to $4 \mathrm { m m } ,$ /year on average for the $_ { 6 - \mathfrak { m } }$ -long fuel channels; that is, strains of 5 to $7 \times$ $1 0 ^ { - 4 }$ /year

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_029_chunk1
evidence_span: strains of 5 to $7 \times$ $1 0 ^ { - 4 }$ /year

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_029_chunk1
evidence_span: Modeling of pressure tube dimensional changes which assumed additivity of creep and growth contributions has attributed up to $80 \%$ of the elongation to irradiation growth

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_029_chunk2
evidence_span: Each reactor cycle necessarily involved a thermal cycle for all the specimens in the rig and therefore all specimens at a given fluence have seen basically the same number of thermal cycles.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_029_chunk2
evidence_span: Following irradiation, cassettes were removed to hot-cell facilities where specimen length measurements could be carried out.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_029_chunk2
evidence_span: The standard deviation on the length measurements in a single orientation obtained in this way was less than $0 . 5 \ \mu \mathrm { m }$ .

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_029_chunk2
evidence_span: Texture—Basal (0002) and prism (1010) pole textures were measured for all three materials. Pole figures for AR and SR material were almost identical (only AR figures are shown) but there were some differences between AR and CW material as can be seen from Fig. 1.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_029_chunk2
evidence_span: Texture—Basal (0002) and prism (1010) pole textures were measured for all three materials. Pole figures for AR and SR material were almost identical (only AR figures are shown) but there were some differences between AR and CW material as can be seen from Fig. 1.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_029_chunk2
evidence_span: Texture—Basal (0002) and prism (1010) pole textures were measured for all three materials. Pole figures for AR and SR material were almost identical (only AR figures are shown) but there were some differences between AR and CW material as can be seen from Fig. 1.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_029_chunk2
evidence_span: The basal pole figure for AR material (Fig. la) is quite typical of Zr-2.5Nb pressure tube: Most of the basal pole intensity is in the radial-transverse plane and the maximum intensity is very close to the transverse direction. There is almost no basal pole intensity in the longitudinal direction.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_029_chunk2
evidence_span: The CW pole figures are qualitatively similar but pole distributions are somewhat modified. There is a higher intensity of basal poles in the transverse direction and the prism poles appear to be more spread out in the radial longitudinal plane.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_029_chunk2
evidence_span: The increase in the intensity of basal poles in the transverse direction on annealing of Zr-2.5Nb material has been previously observed [5] for anneals at 650 and ${ 7 0 0 ^ { \circ } C }$ and must be the result of preferential grain growth of those grains with basal poles close to the transverse direction.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_029_chunk2
evidence_span: The increase in the intensity of basal poles in the transverse direction on annealing of Zr-2.5Nb material has been previously observed [5] for anneals at 650 and ${ 7 0 0 ^ { \circ } C }$ and must be the result of preferential grain growth of those grains with basal poles close to the transverse direction.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_029_chunk4
evidence_span: The Zircaloy-2 has equiaxed grains while the SR material has a two-phase structure of extremely elongated grains

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_029_chunk4
evidence_span: the dislocation density in the SR material is high although mostly recovered, whereas the annealed material would be expected to have a much lower dislocation density

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_029_chunk4
evidence_span: The major alloying element is different (tin versus niobium) although the oxygen contents are similar

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_029_chunk4
evidence_span: The more equiaxed grain structure of CW material compared with the elongated structure of AR material does not have a significant effect upon the growth behavior of Zr-2.5Nb

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_029_chunk4
evidence_span: The growth rate in material with a highly recovered structure decreases with increasing fluence whereas in less-recovered structures the growth rate increases with fluence

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_029_chunk4
evidence_span: The irradiation growth of pressure tube material (AR) is significantly lower than that predicted by the current model for pressure tube elongation
